abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome rating of the
            Electric Cooperative System Loss Reduction Project for the
            Philippines was judged to be moderately satisfactory.  The
            Bank and borrower performance ratings were moderately
            satisfactory. The risk to development outcome was rated
            moderate.  Several lessons were learned.  A good
            understanding of local politics is essential in the design
            stage to ensure a successful project. When preparing the
            program, the Bank should be keenly aware of the local
            politics and be realistic when preparing the pipeline of
            projects. In the Electric Cooperative System Loss Reduction
            Project (ECSLRP), the failure to recognize the vast
            influence of  the National Electrification Administration
            (NEA) over Electric Cooperative (EC) was a key stumbling
            block. It was only after the team recognized this design
            flaw and engaged NEA as a key stakeholder did the project
            take off.  Bank financed projects should, at project start,
            require participants in the program to conform to a uniform
            methodology and procedures/guidelines. The impact of time
            lags on outcomes needs to be considered for selected
            infrastructure projects. System losses are realized with
            investments in infrastructure, most of which will occur over
            time. In this project, Greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions
            avoided would have far exceeded the target if the savings at
            the realization of the investments were taken into account.
            In light of this, there may be a need to review how outcomes
            could be computed, taking into consideration duration of
            project implementation. Distribution projects are not ideal
            for projects that focus on the reduction of GHG emissions.
            Project Development Objectives (PDOs) could be more relevant
            to the development context, rather than focus on Trust Fund
            objectives. While the reduction of system losses was a clear
            area of focus, the Bank could have considered PDOs which
            would be more impactful to the needs of the clients. In
            ECSLRP's design, other economic benefits were not
            considered, which would better reflect the impact of
            programs on the clients and their relevance to
            Governments' priorities.
